abstract: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social media companies like FaceBook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom — and subsequent bust — reverberate among investors.
snippet: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social media companies like FaceBook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom — and subsequent bust — reverberate among investors.
lead_paragraph: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social media companies like Facebook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom — and subsequent bust — reverberate among investors. DealBook spoke to Michael Holland, chairman of Holland & Company, and John C. Coffee, a professor at Columbia Law School, about the structural differences that exist between the dot-com boom of the 1990s and the social media boom of today.

headline.main: The Dot-Com Boom, Then And Now
